1.1 Rationality in Economic Analysis of Law

Economic analysis of law deploys the tools of micro-economic theory to
study legal rules and institutions. The various approaches and
projects within economic analysis of law thus share a common core.
That core consists of the conception of action at the center of
micro-economic
 theory.[1]
 When economic analysis of law first emerged in the 1960s, scholars
adopted the standard rationality assumptions that dominated
microeconomic theory at the time. This practice still dominates the
literature; we shall call it the standard or classical model. In the
1990s, some scholars (see e.g. Jolls, Sunstein, and Thaler [1998])
began to apply the methods of behavioral economics to economic
analysis of law. Behavioral economics rests on a different
understanding of the underpinnings of choice and decision than the
classical model. 
1.1.1 Rationality in the Classical Model

Rational action in economics means that each agent acts to maximize
her “preferences” in whatever environment she finds
herself. A preference is a ranking of the elements in her
domain of preference. The agent’s domain of preference consists
of the things that fundamentally matter to her. In standard models of
consumer behavior, for example, the agent has fundamental preferences
over consumption bundles. Her decision problem consists of choosing a
consumption bundle from the set of feasible consumption bundles, where
feasibility is defined by the prices of goods and the agent’s
income. Arlen and Kornhauser [2021] elaborate on the structure of
preferences in economic analysis of law. 

In most economic analyses of law, the situation is more complex. The
agent has preferences over some set of consequences—her income
or wealth, her state of health, etc.—and she chooses some action
that in part determines which consequence is realized. Typically, her
domain of preference differs from her domain of choice, often because
she chooses a strategy that, in conjunction with the strategy
choices of other agents, jointly determines the consequence. 

At its most abstract level, this conception of rationality is very
flexible as the constraints on preferences are almost purely formal.
(The discussion in section 4 essentially investigates the extent of
this flexibility.) 

Basically, the agent’s ranking of elements of her domain of
preference must be complete and transitive. Completeness means only
that the agent, when presented with any pair A and B of elements in
her domain of preference can rank A and B. That is, the agent either
prefers A to B, prefers B to A, or is indifferent between A and B.
Some, but not all, relations are complete. The relation “Pareto
superior to,” discussed at length in section 6.2, for example,
is not complete.

Transitivity means that if the agent prefers an element A to an
element B and she prefers the element B to a third element C, then she
prefers element A to element C. Many, but not all, relations are
transitive. The relation “friends with,” for example, is
not transitive as A may be friends with B and B may be friends with C
while A and C mutually detest each other. The two conditions are thus
minimal though not empty. 

Every economic analysis of law provides some substantive content to
each agent’s preference ranking. Typically, the analyst
attributes self-interested preferences to each agent. The
agent ranks consequences solely on the basis of their effect on her.
In the standard market model, for example, the agent cares only about
her own consumption not the consumption of others. In the standard
economic model of accident law, she cares only about injuries to
herself and costs that she may incur; she pays no attention to
injuries to others or costs that others incur. 

Of course, one might define “self-interested” in a broad
way to include anything that motivates the agent. Typically, however,
the analyst assumes that the agent’s preferences are
narrowly self-interested; she cares only about her own
economic advantage or her own health and safety. The assumption of
narrowly self-interested preferences is very restrictive. An agent
with narrowly self-interested preferences seems to be incapable of
following a rule or having anything other than a prudential reason for
action. The assumption of narrow self-interest thus seems to limit the
conception of the normativity of law to a bare sanction theory of
duty. We discuss this issue in section 4 below.
1.1.2 Behavioral Economic Analysis of Law

Behavioral economic analysis of law takes three forms. The first
accepts the formal framework of rational choice but rejects the
interpretation of preferences in this framework as self-interested.
Call this the “broad RCT” branch of behavioral economics.
The other two forms of behavioral economics derive from psychology
which seeks to understand the mental processes that agents actually
deploy in their decision making. Both of these forms of behavioral
economics reject the apparent assumption of the classical model that
agents consciously and directly maximize their preferences. But each
form adopts a different stance towards human rationality. The
“fast and frugal heuristics” branch claims that agents are
ecologically rational. The heuristics and biases form of behavioral
economics contends that agents are not rational. We discuss these in
turn. 

The broad RCT approach endorses the formal preference model of the
classical model; it only rejects the narrow interpretation of
preferences as self-interested. Individuals may have
non-self-interested preferences. They may have
“pro-social” preferences that reflect a concern for
others. They may have preferences for “fairness” which
reflect a “preference” for more equal distributions of
benefits and burdens. Indeed, one might posit preferences that reflect
concerns for almost anything. The approach thus risks the ad
hoc ascription of preferences, an issue discussed further in
section 4. 

The ecological rationality school accepts the classical model as a
normative standard against which individual behavior should be
assessed. It rejects the classical model as descriptive of individual
decision procedures. An agent does not solve the optimization problem
that the classical and broad RCT models posit. This school recognizes
that computation is costly and that often the agent lacks adequate
information to complete the calculation. Consequently, individuals
deploy heuristic decision procedures that, under these constraints,
perform well as measured by the RCT model of rationality. 

The heuristics and biases school, by contrast, understands the
existence of heuristics and biases as evidence that individuals behave
irrationally. Any decision process that deviates from classical logic,
Bayesian updating, or strict preference maximization constitutes
irrational behavior. 

Behavioral economic analysis of law typically adapts the classical
model to include a heuristic or bias. The model, that is, specifies a
decision process that, except on the dimension along which the
heuristic or bias works, conforms to the classical model. The analysis
then identifies equilibrium behavior in this model. The structure of
analysis thus parallels the structure of a classical analysis.
